column4: any python gurus around that I can pm, I have a hard question
just ask. Waiting for a guru may take ages. Also, there are other channels specialized on programming.

ok then here it is, I forgot the password to my router so now I have to run a python script that will allow me to access the settings page. I am able to run it on the terminal but it returns a successful access on html code. I need to actually access the settings page on a web browser. Anyway I figured that I had to set up python to work with my apache2 server to try the script. And after some tinkering around it returns thi
s error: http://pastebin.ca/933215 and  here is the code: http://pastebin.ca/933224
can't you do a hard reset on the router? Like with a paper clip or something?
i'd rather not do a hard reset, the code gives a successful 200 ok code and shows some of the html code...I think with a little help i can get it to work
I just noticed that your code gives and indentation error
your index(req) function is empty?
to be honest I don't know a lot about coding, I've been researching the topic for sometime and this is as far as I could get
if i remove the index(req) function the code works under a terminal
well I don't exactly know about sockets, but try commenting out that line "def index(req):"
without the line the script will not show as not found by the web server. However this is what I mean by it working under terminal: http://pastebin.ca/933239
so it works? Now what? You want to send that to a html page?
yes
that's what i've been trying to do
well, I'm not sure. You would need to know which function generates the code and send it to a file object. Or maybe you can just redirect the output like "python getin.py > file.html"
thank you I will start my search in that direction :D
file.html was generated and although it doesn't provide access, it shows the access page saved :)
so, I'm a genius? Or there are still issues?
there are still some issues...as the I only have access to the "saved" file not the actual .htm page
Windows is good or bad is offtopic. Don't discuss it here.
and the actual .htm is in the router, right?
